title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to cronus
text: outlines propose change cronus. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to cronus
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to cronus
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to cronus
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("thechibo/cronus", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to cronus
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to cronus
text: Please note cronus project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with cronus

title: Getting help with cronus
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Data
text: agricultural sector contains crop data measured field reported producers. Examples include crop development, biomass accumulation leaf area index.

title: Data
text: National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) United States Department Agriculture (USDA) conducts hundreds surveys every year prepares reports covering virtually every aspect U.S. agriculture. Production supplies food fiber, prices paid received farmers, farm labor wages, farm finances, chemical use, changes demographics U.S. producers examples. NASS committed providing timely, accurate, useful statistics service U.S. agriculture. information, visit NASS website.

title: Data
text: Quick Stats Database comprehensive tool accessing agricultural data published USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS). Quick Stats contains official published aggregate estimates related U.S. agricultural production, available county, state, country level. data include total crops cropping practices county, breakouts irrigated non-irrigated practices many crops, selected States. database allows custom extracts based commodity, year, selected counties within State, counties one States. county data includes totals Agricultural Statistics Districts (county groupings) State. download data files contain planted harvested area, yield per acre production. NASS develops estimates data collected sample surveys conducted year covering virtually every aspect U.S. agriculture Census Agriculture conducted every five years providing state- county-level aggregates. information, visit NASS website.

title: Data
text: National Agricultural Statistical Service (NASS) offers Cropland Data Layers (CDLs), 1km geospatial maps estimated crop land use. information, visit NASS website.

title: Data
text: environmental sector contains data measured meteorological stations devices, well statistically-predicted data (may based satellite data). Examples include temperature, precipitation soil composition.

title: Data
text: Oak Ridge National Laboratory multiprogram research laboratory managed UT-Battelle, LLC, U.S. Department Energy (DOE). missions ORNL primarily open research. Although small percentage ORNL’s work classified restricted growing national security programs, majority laboratory’s work published open literature. Many facilities user facilities, means available researchers national labs, academia industry. information, visit ORNL website.

title: Data
text: Daymet research product Environmental Sciences Division Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN. provides long-term, continuous, gridded estimates daily weather climatology variables interpolating extrapolating ground-based observations statistical modeling techniques. Daymet data products provide driver data biogeochemical terrestrial modeling. Daymet weather variables include minimum temperature, maximum temperature, precipitation, vapor pressure, shortwave radiation, snow water equivalent, day length produced 1 km x 1 km gridded surface continental North America Hawaii 1980 Puerto Rico 1950 end recent full calendar year. information, visit ORNL website.

title: Examples
text: following example shows work progress variable Quickstats product.
code: # Create the object x <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data variable <- "progress" data <- download(x, variable, ringname) head(data$Corn)  # Read the data progress_2020 <- read(x, variable)  # Plot the data plot(x, variable, year = 2020, crops = c("Corn", "Oats"))

title: Examples
text: following example shows work Cropland Data Layer (CDL) variable Cropmaps product. CDL cropmaps can projected using tmin Daymet variable template (assuming downloaded stored database - see Daymet example). CDL cropmaps rasters holding categorical values (crop names) cells. following example shows access recode values. First , actual rasters hold numeric values, come along data.frame tracks crop name color corresponding number. Function terra::cats() can used see current data.frame. Upon examining current categories, user might want recode . can achieved 2-column matrix, commonly named tb_rcl, holds matching values. two metadata objects can stored database later use, functions write() read(): Recoding straightforward function recode(), uses metadata transform variable interest. variable can also summarized data.frame holding frequency statistics categorical values.
code: # Create the object x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data variable <- "cdl" download(x, variable, ringname)  # Load the data cdl_2020 <- load_map(x, variable)  # Plot the data plot(x, variable, year = 2020, crops = c("Soybeans", "Winter Wheat")) # Create the object y <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date)  # Project the rasters project(x, y, variablex = "cdl", variabley = "tmin", newvarname = "cdl_projected") # Get the current categories data.frame df_cat <- terra::cats(cdl_2020)[[1]]  # Define a transformation table tb_rcl <- cbind(a = c(121:124, 141:143), b = c(rep(82, 4), rep(63, 3)))  # Write the metadata write(x, name = "my_metadata", df_cat = df_cat, tb_rcl = tb_rcl)  # Read the metadata list_md <- read(x, name = "my_metadata") list_md$df_cat list_md$tb_rcl # Recode the raster recode(x, variable = "cdl_projected", mdname = "my_metadata", newvarname = "cdl_recoded")  # Summarize the raster df_summary <- summarize(x, "cdl_recoded")

title: Examples
text: following example shows work tmin tmax variables Daymet product. One important variable concerning crop development thermal time, usually expressed form Growing Degree Days (GDD). concept GDD revolves around crop-specific key-temperatures determine speed development process. cronus database includes Bibliography provider Parameters product, inside kind data can stored. GDD variable can derived using labels CDL cropmaps. GDD can also composed time-series, using CDL variable group crops interest.
code: # Create the object x <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data download(x, c("tmin", "tmax"))  # Plot the data plot(z, "tmin") # Create the object y <- new("Parameters", region = region, date = date)  # Define the cardinal temperatures metadata tb_ct <- rbind('Dry Beans' = c(Tb = 4.0,  To = 23.0, Tc = 32.0),                'Corn'      = c(Tb = 10.0, To = 30.0, Tc = 50.0),                'Soybeans'  = c(Tb = 6.0,  To = 26.0, Tc = 39.0))  # Write the metadata write(y, name = "default", tb_ct = tb_ct)  # Read the metadata tb_ct <- read(y, "default")$tb_ct # Create the object z <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Derive GDD derive(x, z, "gdd", varxy = c("tmin", "tmax", "cdl_recoded"), tb_ct = tb_ct)  # Plot the map plot(x, "gdd") # Compose the rasters into a time-series a <- compose(x, y, variablex = "gdd", variabley = "cdl_recoded", fun = "mean")

title: Examples
text: following example shows work MOD09GA product offers details concerning NDVI variable. following example shows derive NDVI cloudmask variables MOD09GA product. fillgaps() function can used create empty (NA) rasters dates product missing. mask() function can used mask one variable based another. NDVI can smoothed using 1st order whittaker smoother. Date intervals pre post can defined allow better smoothing edges. smoothed NDVI can composed time-series using CDL Cropmaps group crops interest.
code: # Create the object x <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data download(x, ringname) # Derive the NDVI derive(x, "ndvi")  # Derive the cloudmask derive(x, "cloudmask") # Create the NDVI rasters that are missing fillgaps(x, "ndvi")  # Create the cloud mask rasters that are missing fillgaps(x, "cloudmask") # Apply a cloud mask on the NDVI mask(x, "ndvi", "cloudmask") # Smooth the NDVI raster cell time-series smoothout(x, "ndvi", pre = NULL, post = NULL) # Create the object y <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Compose the rasters into a time-series a <- compose(x, y, variablex = "ndvi_smooth_wt1", variabley = "cdl_recoded", fun = "mean")

title: cronus
text: Ages Man project applies advanced statistical methodology remote sensing agriculture. composed several R packages, well elements, one focusing different application. cronus R package focuses database creation. can used download process agricultural, environmental satellite data various sources. vignette contains general information package.

title: cronus
text: database takes form 5-level structured directory. specific region, data can belong one three sectors: agricultural, environmental satellite. Data made available provider, usually organization lab, organizes data one products. product contains several variables interest. can see materials covered package calling function print_tree(). Parent Directory Region, (e.g. nebraska) Sector, (e.g. agricultural) Provider, (e.g. nass) Product, (e.g. cropmaps) Variable, (e.g. cdl) information nature available data products, check ?cronus::'Database-class' read vignette("Data").
code: library(cronus) print_tree() #>  #> Cronus database structure  #>  #>  agricultural  #>     |_ nass  #>         |_ quickstats  #>         |_ cropmaps  #>     |_ bibliography  #>         |_ parameters  #>  #>  environmental  #>     |_ ornl  #>         |_ daymet  #>  #>  satellite  #>     |_ modis  #>         |_ mod09ga  #>         |_ myd09ga  #>     |_ landsat  #>         |_ landsat_tm_c1  #>         |_ landsat_etm_c1  #>         |_ landsat_8_c1  #>     |_ sentinel  #>         |_ s2msi2a  #>         |_ sy_2_syn___

title: cronus
text: package built using S4 class system, offering simplicity new R users well ease development project core team. Functions require single object holds necessary information concerning data interest: region, object class Region indicating region interest, date, object class Date indicating time interest dir, object class character indicating parent directory database. Now, straightforward create data object: package functions, download() generic S4 functions, meaning depending class object provided user, can different behavior. Therefore, user needs provide product object along variables interest function rest: Functions download process data automatically store database. means user never deal directories explicitly. Note: functions may require seconds equipped progress bar indicating percentage completed, well estimated time remaining. now ready read vignette("Examples").
code: region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state", div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- as.Date("2020-07-15") dir <- getwd()  w <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) y <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) z <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) ?cronus::download download(w, "progress") download(x, "cdl") download(y, c("tmin", "tmax")) download(z)

title: cronus
text: order avoid specifying database directory every single function call, variable named path_demeter can added environment variables, stored user project .Renviron file. allows user specify database directory, load beginning every R session. Function set_path_demeter() can used specify change path.
code: set_path_demeter(path = getwd(), level = "user")

title: cronus
text: Many organizations require credentials order allow data download. Currently, user needs credentials following services: USDA: Provides access NASS Quickstats data. USGS: Provides access Modis Images. USGS sole science agency Department Interior United States. EarthData: repository NASA’s earth observation data-sets. SciHub: web service giving access Copernicus’ scientific data hub. order safely store API keys passwords, R package keyring used. can always store credentials another safe place, just make sure made publicly available mistake. keyring account can hold keys (credentials) various services. keyring created, user can start adding keys . following example shows create keyring store credentials. Functions require credentials can automatically get user logged . Users reminded log safety reasons.
code: ringname <- "my_ringname"  password <- "my_password"   create_keyring(ringname, password)   log_in(ringname, password)   add_key(ringname = ringname,          provider = "usgs",          username = "usgs_username",          password = "usgs_password")   get_username(ringname, "usgs")  get_password(ringname, "usgs")   log_out(ringname)

title: Agricultural Remote Sensing Database Constructor
text: Ages Man project applies advanced statistical methodology remote sensing agriculture. composed several R packages, well elements, one focusing different application. cronus R package focuses database creation. can used download process agricultural, environmental satellite data various sources.

title: Agricultural Remote Sensing Database Constructor
text: can install stable version cronus CRAN running following line code: can install development version cronus github running following line code: instead recommended install entirety Ages Man project. details can found agesofman Github repository.
code: install.packages("cronus") devtools::install_github("agesofman/cronus")

title: Agricultural Remote Sensing Database Constructor
text: Detailed documentation, along reproducible examples, can found package vignettes.
code: vignette(topic = "cronus", package = "cronus") vignette(topic = "Data", package = "cronus") vignette(topic = "Download", package = "cronus") vignette(topic = "Process", package = "cronus")

title: Agricultural Remote Sensing Database Constructor
text: Ages Man project developed Mathematics Department University Athens. project maintainer Ioannis Oikonomidis, working supervision Prof. Samis Trevezas.

title: Cronus database classes — Database-class
text: cronus creates database, takes form 5-level directory. levels Region > Sector > Provider > Product > Variable. specific region, data can belong one three sectors: agricultural, environmental satellite. Data made available provider, usually organization lab, organizes data one products. product contains several variables interest. class tree structure following: Agricultural Sector Nass Provider Quickstats Product Cropmaps Product Bibliography Provider Parameters Product Environmental Sector Ornl Provider Daymet Product Satellite Sector Modis Provider Mod09ga Product Myd09ga Product Landsat Provider Landsat_tm_c1 Product Landsat_etm_c1 Product Landsat_8_c1 Product Sentinel Provider S2msi2a Product Sy_2_syn___ Product Classes Database, Sector, Provider, Product also defined, abstract classes exist solely hierarchical purposes.

title: Cronus database classes — Database-class
text: S4 object appropriate class (constructor functions).

title: Cronus database classes — Database-class
text: region Region. region interest. date Date. Dates interest (vector). dir character. database parent directory. path_demeter environment variable set, can omitted.

title: Cronus database classes — Database-class
code: if (FALSE) { region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- as.Date("2020-07-15") dir <- getwd()  w <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) y <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date, dir = dir) z <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date, dir = dir)  }

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose
code: compose(x, y, ...)  # S4 method for Database,Cropmaps compose(x, y, variablex, variabley, fun = "mean", ...)

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose
text: x S4 object. product interest. y S4 object. product determining zones. ... extra arguments passed fun. variablex character. variable product x. variabley character. variable product y. fun character function. function apply summaries.

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose
text: data.frame zonal summaries. data.frame also saved cronus database .csv format.

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose
text: Currently, y can NASS Cropmap.

title: Compose rasters by maps — compose
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Daymet  # Create objects x <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date) y <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Compose a <- compose(x, y, variablex = "gdd",  variabley = "cdl_default", fun = "mean") b <- compose(x, y, variablex = "prcp", variabley = "cdl_default", fun = "mean")  ## MOD09GA  # Create objects x <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date) y <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  a <- compose(x, y, variablex = "ndvi_smooth_wt1", variabley = "cdl_recoded", fun = "mean") }

title: Manage keys and keyrings — create_keyring
text: set function wrappers keyring package. keyring account can hold keys (credentials) various services. keyring created, user can start adding keys . Functions cronus package require credentials can automatically get provided ringname. Users reminded log-log-order use keyrings.

title: Manage keys and keyrings — create_keyring
text: create_keyring(): Create keyring. delete_keyring(): Delete keyring. log_in(): Log keyring. log_out(): Log keyring. add_key(): Add key keyring. get_username(): Get username. get_password(): Get password. delete_key(): Delete key. check_keyring(): Check whether user logged-.

title: Manage keys and keyrings — create_keyring
code: if (FALSE) { ringname <- "my_ringname" password <- "my_password"  create_keyring(ringname, password) check_keyring(ringname)  log_in(ringname, password) check_keyring(ringname)  add_key(ringname = ringname, provider = "nass", username = NULL, password = "nass_key")  add_key(ringname = ringname,         provider = "usgs",         username = "usgs_username",         password = "usgs_password")  get_username(ringname, "usgs") get_password(ringname, "usgs") delete_key(ringname, "usgs")  log_out(ringname) delete_keyring(ringname) }

title: cronus: Agricultural Remote Sensing Database Constructor — cronus-package

title: Derive data — derive
text: Derive variables based existing data.

title: Derive data — derive
code: derive(x, ...)  # S4 method for Daymet derive(x, y, variable, varxy, ...)  # S4 method for Satellite derive(x, variable)

title: Derive data — derive
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments variable. y S4 object. product interest. variable character. function compute variable interest. varxy character. Variables used derive variable.

title: Derive data — derive
text: nothing. data saved directly cronus database.

title: Derive data — derive
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Daymet  # Create objects x <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date) y <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Create parameters (cardinal temperatures) z <- new("Parameters", region = region, date = date) tb_ct <- read(z, "default")$tb_ct  # Derive gdd (take a look at the gdd function) derive(x, y, "gdd", varxy = c("tmin", "tmax", "cdl_default"), tb_ct = tb_ct)  ## MOD09GA  # Create objects x <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date)  # Derive ndvi and cloudmask derive(x, "ndvi") derive(x, "cloudmask") }

title: Download data — download
text: Download agricultural, environmental, satellite data region time interest.

title: Download data — download
code: download(x, ...)  # S4 method for Quickstats download(x, variable, ringname = NULL)  # S4 method for Cropmaps download(x, variable = NULL)  # S4 method for Daymet download(x, variable = NULL)  # S4 method for Satellite download(x, ringname = NULL)

title: Download data — download
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments. variable character. variable interest. ringname character. keyring handle provider credentials.

title: Download data — download
text: products, nothing returned. data saved directly cronus database. lightweight data (variables Quickstats product), downloaded data returned.

title: Download data — download
text: Currently, function can download: Quickstats product NASS. Cropland Data Layer variable NASS. Daymet product ORNL. MOD09GA MYD09GA products MODIS. Landsat TM, ETM 8 products. Sentinel-2 MSI Sentinel-3 Synergy products. Details concerning Quickstats product: function wrapper nassqs() function rnassqs package. order download data, API key required; information can found rnassqs package vignette. Details concerning Daymet product: S4 class Daymet can used handle data daymet product. wrapper get_daymet() function FedData package. Details concerning satellite sector: function uses rsat::rsat_search() function search available products requested dates. , recursively calls rsat::rsat_download() rsat::rsat_mosaic() download mosaic data, deleting original hdf files save disk space. satellite data extracted GeoTiff format (zipped). recursive call function slight performance impact, crucial order download data large regions periods time. example, assume want download MOD09GA product state Nebraska one day. (3) hdf files required combined surpass 250MB memory space, mosaiced, zipped Geotiff images take 15MB.

title: Download data — download
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Quickstats Progress  # Create the object x <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data data <- download(x, "progress", ringname) head(data$Corn)  ## Cropmaps CDL  # Create the object x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data download(x, "cdl")  ## Daymet  # Create the object x <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data download(x, c("tmin", "tmax"))  ## MOD09GA  # Create the object x <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date)  # Download the data download(x, ringname) }

title: Manage database — get_branch
text: Get relative absolute path branch cronus database.

code: get_branch(   dir = NULL,   region = NULL,   sector = NULL,   provider = NULL,   product = NULL,   variable = NULL )  create_db(   dir = NULL,   region = NULL,   sector = NULL,   provider = NULL,   product = NULL,   variable = NULL )  print_tree()

title: Manage database — get_branch
text: dir character. database parent directory. region Region region interest. sector character. sector interest. provider character. provider interest. product character. product interest. variable character. variable interest.

title: Manage database — get_branch
text: get_branch() returns list containing path (absolute relative, depending whether parent directory provided ), well arguments provided extrapolated . create_db() creates directory specified, get_branch()$path, returns path invisibly. print_tree() prints database structure Sector - Provider - Product tree form.

title: Manage database — get_branch
code: if (FALSE) { region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska"))  list_cropmaps <- get_branch(dir = getwd(), region = region, product = "cropmaps") list_cropmaps$dir list_cropmaps$region list_cropmaps$sector list_cropmaps$provider list_cropmaps$product list_cropmaps$variable list_cropmaps$path  path_cropmaps <- create_db(dir = getwd(), region = region, product = "cropmaps") }

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
text: .Rprofile .Renviron files loaded start-R session. can modified contain code variables respectively, users explicitly execute commands every single time. functions can help users edit .Rprofile .Renviron files without actually opening .

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
code: get_startup_path(level, type = "environ")  read_startup(level = "user", type = "environ")  remove_startup_line(oldline, level = "user", type = "environ")  add_startup_line(newline, oldline = newline, level = "user", type = "environ")

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
text: level character. level file, one 'user' 'project'. type character. type, one 'environ' 'profile'. oldline character. Line remove adding new one. newline character. Line add file.

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
text: multiple locations .Rprofile .Renviron files stored. function can modify 'user' 'project' files. , 'project' refers RStudio project. examples show possible locations startup files. See also Startup. Argument oldline used remove duplicate lines code. can specified regex look complex code expressions remove . examples show one instance.

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
text: get_startup_path(): Returns .Renviron .Rprofile file path. read_startup(): Read .Renviron .Rprofile file. remove_startup_line(): Remove line code .Renviron .Rprofile file. add_startup_line(): Add line code .Renviron .Rprofile file.

title: Handle .Rprofile and .Renviron — get_startup_path
code: if (FALSE) { # Locations of .Rprofile files in loading order Sys.getenv("R_PROFILE") file.path(Sys.getenv("R_HOME"), "etc", "Rprofile.site") Sys.getenv("R_PROFILE_USER") file.path(getwd(), ".Rprofile") file.path(Sys.getenv("HOME"), ".Rprofile") # 'level = user'.  # Locations of .Renviron files in loading order Sys.getenv("R_ENVIRON") file.path(Sys.getenv("R_HOME"), "etc", "Renviron.site") Sys.getenv("R_ENVIRON_USER") file.path(getwd(), ".Renviron") file.path(Sys.getenv("HOME"), ".Renviron") # 'level = user'.  # Get the path level <- "user" type <- "environ" get_startup_path(level = level, type = type)  # Edit the file newline1 <- "my_variable=1" newline2 <- "my_variable=2" add_startup_line(newline1, level = level, type = type) file_startup_1 <- read_startup(level = level, type = type) add_startup_line(newline2, oldline = 'my_variable=', level, type) file_startup_2 <- read_startup(level = level, type = type)  # Use the package usethis to edit the files directly library(usethis) edit_r_profile(scope = "user") edit_r_environ(scope = "user") }

title: Plot — plot
text: Create plot data stored database.

title: Plot — plot
code: plot(x, y, ...)  # S4 method for Quickstats,character plot(   x,   y,   year,   crops = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   ylab = "Percentage",   xlab = "Time",   save = FALSE,   dir = getwd(),   file = "plot.pdf",   width = 15,   height = 8 )  # S4 method for Cropmaps,character plot(x, y, crops = NULL, year = NULL)  # S4 method for Daymet,character plot(x, y, date = NULL)

title: Plot — plot
text: x S4 object. product interest. y character. variable interest. ... extra arguments. year numeric. Year(s) interest. crops character. crops interest. ncol numeric. Number rows plot layout. nrow numeric. Number columns plot layout. ylab character. y-axis title. xlab character. x-axis title. save logical. plot saved? dir character. directory plot saved. file character. file name. width numeric. width plot inches. height numeric. height plot inches. date character Date(s) interest.

title: Plot — plot
text: plot, created either ggplot2 terra.

title: Plot — plot
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Quickstats Progress  # Create the object x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Plot variable <- "cdl" plot(x, variable, crops = c("Soybeans", "Winter Wheat"), year = 2002)  ## Daymet Tmin  # Create the object x <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date, dir = dir)  # Plot plot(x, "tmin", "2002-01-01") }

code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Cropmaps CDL and Daymet  # Create objects x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date) y <- new("Daymet", region = region, date = date)  # Project project(x, y, variablex = "cdl", variabley = "tmin", "cdl_projected") }

title: Read data — read
text: Read data stored cronus database.

title: Read data — read
code: read(x, ...)  # S4 method for Quickstats read(x, variable)  # S4 method for Cropmaps read(x, name)  # S4 method for Parameters read(x, name)  # S4 method for Daymet read(x, variable)  # S4 method for Mod09ga read(x, variable)  # S4 method for Database read(x, df_var)

title: Read data — read
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments. variable character. variable interest. name character. name metadata files. df_var data.frame. data frame columns Product Variable.

title: Read data — read
text: data interest (list, data.frame, raster, ).

title: Read data — read
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Quickstats Progress  # Create the object x <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date)  # Read the data variable <- "progress" list_progress <- read(x, variable)  ## Parameters  # Create the object x <- new("Parameters", region = region, date = date)  # Read the data read(x, name = "default") }

title: Recode data — recode
text: Recode variables using metadata.

title: Recode data — recode
code: recode(x, ...)  # S4 method for Cropmaps recode(x, variable, mdname, newvarname = variable)

title: Recode data — recode
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments. variable character. variable interest. mdname character. metadata file names needed recoding. newvarname character. name recoded variable.

title: Recode data — recode
text: nothing. data saved directly cronus database.

title: Recode data — recode
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Cropmaps CDL  # Create the object x <- new("Cropmaps", region = region, date = date)  # Get the current categories data.frame df_cat <- terra::cats(cdl_2020)[[1]]  # Define a transformation table tb_rcl <- cbind(a = c(121:124, 141:143), b = c(rep(82, 4), rep(63, 3)))  # Write the metadata write(x, name = "my_metadata", df_cat = df_cat, tb_rcl = tb_rcl)  # Recode the raster recode(x, variable = "cdl_projected", mdname = "my_metadata", newvarname = "cdl_recoded") }

title: Smooth raster time-series — smoothout
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments. variable character. variable interest. smoother character. function applied original data. pre character. vector dates used extra smoothing window dates interest. post character. vector dates used extra smoothing window dates interest.

title: Smooth raster time-series — smoothout
text: nothing. smoothed data saved directly cronus database.

title: Smooth raster time-series — smoothout
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## MOD09GA  # Create the object x <- new("Mod09ga", region = region, date = date)  # Smooth the raster cell time-series smoothout(x, "ndvi", pre = NULL, post = NULL) }

title: Write metadata — write_metadata
text: Write metadata files cronus database.

title: Write metadata — write_metadata
code: write_metadata(x, ...)  # S4 method for Cropmaps write_metadata(x, name, df_cat = NULL, tb_rcl = NULL)  # S4 method for Parameters write_metadata(x, name, tb_ct = NULL)

title: Write metadata — write_metadata
text: x S4 object. product interest. ... extra arguments. name character. name metadata files. df_cat data.frame data frame holding cdl categories. tb_rcl matrix matrix holding cdl value recoding. tb_ct matrix. matrix holding cardinal temperatures.

title: Write metadata — write_metadata
text: nothing. data saved directly cronus database.

title: Write metadata — write_metadata
code: if (FALSE) { # Define required variables region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state",                  div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska")) date <- date_seq("2002-01-01", "2002-12-31")  ## Parameters  # Create the object x <- new("Parameters", region = region, date = date)  # Define the cardinal temperatures metadata tb_ct <- rbind('Dry Beans' = c(Tb = 4.0,  To = 23.0, Tc = 32.0),                'Corn'      = c(Tb = 10.0, To = 30.0, Tc = 50.0),                'Soybeans'  = c(Tb = 6.0,  To = 26.0, Tc = 39.0))  # Write the metadata write_metadata(y, name = "default", tb_ct = tb_ct) }

title: Whittaker 1st order smoother — wt1
text: Apply whittaker 1st order smoother matrix.

title: Whittaker 1st order smoother — wt1
code: wt1(x, lambda = 50)

title: Whittaker 1st order smoother — wt1
text: x matrix. data smooth row. lambda numeric. smoother parameter.

title: Whittaker 1st order smoother — wt1
text: matrix dimensions x.

title: Whittaker 1st order smoother — wt1
code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(12029) n <- 20 x <- matrix(1:n + rnorm(n), nrow = 1, ncol = n) x[ , 5] <- NA y <- wt1(x, lambda = 2) plot(x[1, ]) lines(y[1, ], col = "blue") }

title: cronus 0.0.3
text: Added NEWS.md file track changes package. Improved vignettes. Added tests testthat. Added Codecov test coverage covr. Added cran-comments.md. Performed checks (R CMD, Build windows binary package, CRAN).
